reviewText: As I watched young 'Gust' Dudamel's DVD that showcased Dvorak's 'New World' Symphony, somebody reminded me of this 2002 DVD featuring Claudio Abbado and Berlin Phil.And a big 'wow' to Abbado's conducting. The New World is breathtakingly touching. Don't for once think that a conductor over 70 years of age lacks prowess or charisma as compared to one in twenties.  Claudio is as forceful and fiery as ever.And being the best conductor of concertos, the Brahms Violin Concerto Op. 77 featuring Gil Shaham is another wonder piece that no one could afford to miss.There are by now numerous recording of this piece,and numerous concert performances. The standard set here by Abbado/Shaham remains to be surpassed.The screen play for this DVD is absolutely first class. Just one small question - it focused many times more on the first flautist than the first violinist. (Of course we all know that the first flautist is none other than Emanuel Pahud, the star flautist of this generation).
Title: N/A

reviewText: As the reviewers below have pointed out, this is just a fantastic release -- one of the very best orchestral concerts on DVD.The Egmont overture is played very fleetly and brilliantly (similar to the Beethoven in Abbado's BPO symphony cycle).  The Brahms is a given a passionate, committed performance by Gil Shaham (who indeed sweats up a storm).  A particularly wonderful moment is the beginning of the slow movement which (I realized watching this performance) is almost a mini-serenade for wind instruments and is gloriously played by the BPO's peerless wind section.The Dvorak is stunning -- played with fire and beauty and total precision, and the whole orchestra seems to be having a ball.  As mentioned by the other reviewer, the English Horn solo is absolutely breathtaking in the slow movement, I've never heard the instrument sound so hauntingly beautiful before.The Verdi Vespri Siciliani encore is a thrilling and delightful conclusion.The DVD looks great and is in anamorphic widescreen, and the direction is superb -- better than any other orchestral DVD I know.  Every shot seems to be focused on just the right instrument (and, in many instances, highlighting a marvelous and unexpected orchestral detail that Abbado has brought out).This was one of Abbado's last concerts as director of the BPO, and though one hesitates to read to much into these things, the performance really does seem like a love song from the orchestra to Abbado.  A great souvenir of a great occasion.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Words rarely fail me. But I'm almost speechless with delight over this DVD of the Europa-Konzert (European Concert) given May 1, 2002 in the magnificent newly-restored Teatro Massimo in Palermo, Sicily. Everything about it delights.The Europa-Konzert is a Berlin Philharmonic tradition. Every May 1st they give a concert in some city in Europe to commemorate the founding of their orchestra on May Day 1882. Up to now the Lisbon Concert conducted by Pierre Boulez had been my favorite, but this one takes the prize. It is conducted by Claudio Abbado, and was the last one he conducted before he ended his twelve-year reign as music director of the orchestra. He had been through a major illness, and looks gaunt, although he sports a deep tan. There has always been something saintly about Abbado's appearance but that is enhanced here. And certainly one who knows his health problems is all the more tempted to give him some slack for sentimental reasons. But there is no reason to do that here. This is a superlative concert, both for the orchestra's playing and for Abbado's conception of the works presented.The concert begins with an exciting performance of Beethoven's 'Egmont' Overture. And then Gil Shaham, surely one of the handful of really great violinists on the scene, plays the Brahms Violin Concerto. Rarely have I heard such a combination of technical ease and deeply musical expressivity in this thrice-familiar masterpiece. The Adagio is particularly moving. The long opening oboe solo, played by Albrecht Mayer, is meltingly beautiful; Shaham's playing here is ethereally haunting. There is no dearth of violinistic fireworks in the outer movements. This is then followed by a sublime reading of Dvorák's 'New World Symphony.' If I had to single out a section that moved me the most it would be that so-familiar second movement with its English horn solo playing what most of know as 'Going Home.' I was so impressed by the English hornist's playing that I went to the Berliner Philharmoniker website to find out his name so I could include it here: Dominik Wollenweber. Abbado chooses a slower than usual tempo for this movement and time seems to stand still. Without question this is the best performance of that movement that I've ever heard.After a thunderous ovation from the Palermo audience, Abbado returns to the stage to lead an encore, the aptly chosen Overture to Verdi's 'Sicilian Vespers.'A few other comments. In Abbado's tenure with the orchestra there was a huge turnover in personnel as many of Karajan's stalwarts retired. Seventy new musicians joined the orchestra while Abbado was there,  most of them quite young. Emanuel Pahud, the new principal flutist, was only 23 when he joined, and of course he has now forged a huge career as a concertizing soloist as well. From the looks of it, Wollenweber couldn't be more than mid-twenties, but such playing! But the most notable thing is the incredible quality of the playing. This orchestra breathes together, performs with split-second synchronization that may be the best in the world, and with deep musicianship. Every serious music lover has a list of 'before I die I want to hear ...' list. Mine includes hearing the Berlin Philharmonic live in concert. What an orchestra!Well, enough gushing, particularly for someone who started out saying he was lost for words. I don't often say this, but I urge anyone who loves great orchestral playing to get this DVD.TT = 112 minutes. Sound formats include DD 5.1, DTS 5.1, PCM stereo. Sound quality is excellent. Videography and direction for TV is crisp and inobtrusive. Extra: a very nice twenty minute documentary about Palermo, focusing primarily on the arts, architecture and music primarily.Scott Morrison

reviewText: No need to elaborate too much here: this is THE best concert DVD in my collection, period. Every single positive comment in the other reviews here is true. It is simply an incredible production, from whatever aspect you look at it - the repertoire, location, orchestra, video, sound, extras and everything else is magnificent. Don't know if I'll ever come across a concert DVD better than this one.Well done EuroArts, Claudio Abbado and the BPO - from now on this will the benchmark on my home theater setup for all other DVDs I buy.

reviewText: I must say that, once again, I agree with the authoritative J. Scott Morrison, as well as with several others here, but, I'd still like to put in my own oar, such as it is.  I think we must say that simply on the strength of the stupendous, virtuoso performance of the encore, Verdi's overture to "The Sicilian Vespers," that Claudio Abbado is the greatest conductor now before the public. Of course, we have to add that the Berlin Philharmonic is perhaps the greatest orchestra, but it is the absolutely compelling conducting of Abbado which creates a performance of such exciting brilliance that we must rank him with Arturo Toscanini in presenting the music of Verdi.  I know that he is currently involved with the Lucerne Festival and with other orchestral projects, but I'm sure that if Maestro Abbado would conduct some Verdi, it would be great, if not historic. His reading of the "Requiem" is already justly esteemed, so why not stage "Il Trovatore" or another great Verdi opera?I'd also like to comment briefly on the performance of the Brahms Violin Concerto with Gil Shaham.  Abbado's  acclaimed performances of the Brahms Symphonies are already well-known, so we expect that he would do equally well here, and we are not disappointed. The orchestral part receives a fine performance that would inspire any soloist, and Shaham really digs in a la Oistrach.  This approach works especially well in the rondo, in which the infectious rhythm in Shaham's playing seems to carry everyone along with an almost peasant-like joy.The "New World" is given an equally enjoyable performance, and the excellent sound of this DVD allows us to hear Dvorak's many inner voices as clearly as if we're present, in the beautiful opera house of Palermo.  Of course, Abbado's conducting is certainly a great factor in the success of this piece, as well as of the entire concert.  The final reaction of the audience is really touching (a floral fusillade from the balcony), since this was Claudio Abbado's last tour with his orchestra, the one he built into the finest in Europe. The love of his musicians and of his public is quite clear through the fond smiles and flowers, you'll see in the crystal clear picture quality of this excellent Euro Arts DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Another fabulous DVD from EuroartsThis disc, featuring the Berlin Philharmonic Symphony (BPO), is one of a series that has been recorded in May of each year from various European locales (To commemorate the founding of the BPO on May 1, 1882). This recording, in 2002, is from the glorious Teatro Massimo in Palermo, Sicily, with the BPO under the baton of Claudio Abbado.The composers featured are the finest the 18th and 19th centuries had to offer; Beethoven (Egmont Overture), Brahms ( Violin concerto in D with Gil Shaham*),  Drovak (Symphony # 9, From the New World) and Verdi (Sicilian Vespers)Everything about this DVD is top notch...let me elaborateThe setting is sumptuous; the newly renovated (1997) Teatro Massimo is a show piece of consummate proportions. It has six levels of private wall lodges surrounding the entire outer edge of the main floor; this would make for spectacular, private viewing. The domed ceiling, with its hand painted, petal shaped design, is as much an attraction as the theater itself. How proud the people of Palermo must be of this magnificent structure.The video is superbly done. There are close ups of individuals and instruments as well as panoramic views of the orchestra and also the inside of the theater itself. The editing reflects a knowledge of the music being played as evidenced by the switching of the camera to the most appropriate view; this was done with impeccable timing and great effect.The audio: simply superb!  Enough said.The performance: As good as I could ever have hoped for; and what a bonus to have these 4 masterpieces on one DVD. It would be near impossible to pick one piece as the best on the disc; they are all that well done.All in  all, Euroarts has produced a recording that exemplifies why a DVD with its video  capabilities, has so much more to offer than the same product with only an audio (CD). This recording would be great simply to listen to, but the video simply enhances the pleasure of viewing this wonderful recording. Highly recommended!* Mr. Shaham plays the Countess Polignac Strad, built in 1699. It has, in my opinion, the finest sounding G and D strings I've ever heard on any Strad. (but then maybe it's the way Mr Shaham plays them)
summary: Abbado and the Berlin Philharmonic in Palermo...truly magnificent
Title: N/A

reviewText: First if you are looking for the definitive New World be aware that this disk has the same New World as the Discover series with the 30 minute commentary, Get this disk and you will not only have an inspired New World,, but a remarkable Brahms violin concerto by the very talented Gil Shaham. I have the Brahms violin concerto by Perlman, and I must say they are equally as talented. The bonus here are the two overtures. The video quality is just a notch below true Blu-ray and is one third the cost. DTS5.1 audio is excellent and the Palermo theater is gorgeous. I found the video direction superb with just the right amount of focus on the orchestra and Abaddo, unlike Karajan where there is much more focus on the conductor. The occasional pan of the Palermo theater is warranted,Getting back to the New World...this is one of those rare inspired performances that you will play over and over. If you want a commentary on Dvorak get the Teaching company lectures by Professor Greenberg.
Title: N/A

reviewText: After such a long awaiting, this dvd was finally released on NTSC. I bought this dvd mainly because of the vilolinist Gil Shaham and the great repertoire. I had never seen the Brahams' violin concert performed either on stage or any kind of video media. What a thrilling moment to watch Gil Shaham play was! He plays with all his passion and energy. He sweats tons of sweat like a river while he plays. To me, his rendition was just perfect with such hamonious accompaniment by the world's finest orchestra. It was a million dollar performance. I just hope I could see him perform in person sometime.Abbado's rendition of Beethoven's "Egmont", one of my favorite overtures, was a bit disappointing. I think it was played a bit too lightly and fast. It was therefore not very dramatic and solemn to listen to as is supposed to be. However, "New World Symphony" was brilliant and magnificient. All movements were quite good. The 2nd movement was particularly impressive as previous reviewer mentioned. It was very lyrical and idyllic. The oboe sounded different and unique than any other players' I'd ever heard. Camera work was also great in this movement. It followed the atmosphere by using fade-in and -out. I liked the other movements too. Wind instruments couldn't sound better. I only wished the camera work had done as good as in 2nd movement.all in all, this is one of the most collectible and enjoyable concert dvds. This really is worth owning. I am grateful for EuroArts, the finest production in the world. I've bought many dvds produced by EuroArt, which relieves my thirst for "quality" classical concert dvds. Bravo, keep up the good work, EuroArts!
summary: Ovation to Gil Shaham and Abbado's Dvorak...
